Graphical abstract The fully conjugated porphyrin framework (A-PpazoPorCo) modified by electron donor group was synthesized by adjusting the reaction ratio, which is supported on 3D-G by π-π interaction. –Ph–NH2 increased the electron cloud density of Co–N4 center, showing excellent oxygen reaction bi-functional activity. Fully conjugated covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are widely used in electrocatalysis. The COF with –ph–NH2 edge poly(1,4-phenyldiazo porphyrin cobalt) (A-PpazoPorCo) is synthesized by adjusting the molar ratio of the reaction material, and exhibits high delocalization energy to significantly enhance thermal stability. The nitrogen in the azo bond improves the adsorption capacity for ORR and OER catalytic intermediates, while the –ph–NH2 group further increases the electron cloud density at the Co–N4 center in A-PpazoPorCo. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the strong electron-donating –ph–NH2 groups and the electron-donating azo bonds form an electron donor-π-electron acceptor (D-π-A) structure, which further enhances the electron cloud density. The strong π-π interaction between A-PpazoPorCo and three-dimensional graphene (3D-G) significantly boosts the oxygen catalytic performance of the A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G. The catalytic ORR half-wave potential (E 1/2) of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G can reach 0.880 V vs. RHE. The total overpotential (△E = E j=10-E 1/2) is 0.617 V, demonstrating excellent bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance. The efficient oxygen catalytic performance indicates that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has the potential for application in fuel cells cathodes and overall water splitting anodes. Keywords Bifunctional oxygen reaction catalyst Fully conjugated COFs Azo-bridged porphyrin cobalt Electron donor groups π-π interaction 1 Introduction The constraints of sustainable development in the future are represented by the dual crises of energy scarcity and environmental pollution. It is therefore imperative to develop new energy sources in order to alleviate these problems [1,2]. Fuel cells are a new energy technology that can relieve the serious energy crisis and environmental pollution. In fuel cells, the hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) takes place at the anode, whereas the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) occurs at the cathode. Overall water splitting (OWS) represents a powerful technology with the potential to achieve carbon neutrality [3,4]. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is an important reaction of OWS [5]. However, the slow reaction dynamics of ORR and OER seriously hinder their development [6]. Developing bifunctional catalysts for oxygen reactions is thus a critical step towards advancing fuel cells and OWS technology [7,8]. Zinc-air batteries (ZABs) are an energy conversion device with high theoretical energy density involving ORR in discharged reaction and OER in charging reaction [9]. The ORR and OER properties of oxygen electrode catalysts are fully reflected in ZABs [10,11]. Therefore, ZABs are an effective bifunctional catalyst device for evaluating oxygen reactions. At present, the primary cathode catalysts of fuel cells and ZABs are noble metal catalysts, among which platinum–carbon catalysts are mainly used in catalytic ORR reaction catalysis, and their catalytic OER reaction performance is poor [12,13]. However, RuO2 and IrO2 are mainly used in catalytic OER reaction catalysis, yet their catalytic ORR reaction kinetics is relatively slow [14,15]. It is therefore imperative to develop a class of non-noble metal catalysts with bifunctional performance for oxygen reactions to meet the requirements of commercial applications [16–18]. At present, the main non-precious metal catalysts are transition metal oxides [19–22], transition metal chalcogenides [23], transition metal nitrogen carbon catalyst [24] and transition metal macrocyclic complex catalysts [25]. In the natural environment, porphyrins have been employed as catalytic ORR catalysts due to their distinctive conjugated structure. The porphyrins used to be decomposed into M−N−C atomic clusters at heat treatment (HT) as fuel cells catalysts. Upon the decomposition of porphyrins into M−N−C atomic clusters, their active sites become ambiguous, thereby influencing their catalytic performance. To solve this problem, porphyrins can be linked to form conjugated polymers, which increase the delocalization energy of porphyrins to improve their thermal stability [26]. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are a class of porous polymers connected by organic building blocks, which have been widely studied in the field of electrocatalysis due to their regular pore structure, high specific surface area and abundant active sites [27–30]. COFs that have been reported can be classified into the following categories: (1) COFs that are connected by conventional covalent bonds can also coordinate with transition metals [31,32]. Generally, the conjugation of these COFs is incomplete, leading to poor thermal stability, and they are prone to decomposition at HT, forming M−N−C atomic clusters, which negatively impacts their catalytic performance. (2) Non-sp 2 hybridized COFs are connected by porphyrins metal (PorM), while PorM needs to activated better catalytic performance through HT, where the non-fully conjugated system leads to poor thermal stability. During HT processes, these COFs are also decomposed into M−N−C atomic clusters, further impacting their stability and performance. (3) Full conjugated PorM-COFs (FC-PorM-COFs) which contains large π bonds in the molecule has high delocalization energy, the thermal stability of the molecules is enhanced, and it is not decomposed at HT [33]. FC-PorM-COFs has smaller HOMO-LUMO band gap, higher ability to gain and lose electrons, and has better catalytic activity in catalysis [34,35]. At present, the synthesis of FC-PorM-COFs is mainly through Schiff base reaction [36], cyano-self-polymerization [37], Friedel-Crafts alkylation [38], self-polymerization [39] and other methods to synthesize different two-dimensional planar fully conjugate structure. The previously reported FC-PorM-COFs connected by azo bonds have planar large π bonds and has better thermal stability [40]. The nitrogen of the azo bond can improve the adsorption capacity of the catalytic ORR and OER intermediates, thus further improving the catalytic performance of oxygen [41,42]. Recently, it has been reported that FePPc modified with different electron-donor/electron-withdrawing groups was prepared in situ on acetylene black, and FePPc-R/C was obtained without HT. The catalytic oxygen reaction activity of the catalyst was studied, and it was concluded that the introduction of electron-withdrawing groups could improve the catalytic performance of the catalyst [43]. This is not a conventional conclusion. In general, electron donating groups can further increase the electron cloud density of Co–N4 center in PorM, thus improving the catalytic oxygen reaction performance. What kind of structure can improve the catalytic performance of FC-PorM-COFs connected by azo bond? The introduction of strong electron-donor –ph–NH2 and azo bond bridges at the same time to obtain A-PpazoPorCo (The structural formulas of A-PpazoPorCo is shown in Fig. S4.) has the following advantages: (1) Large π bonds can be formed in the whole plane, which has high delocalization energy and improves the thermal stability of A-PpazoPorCo; (2) A-PpazoPorCo have smaller HOMO-LUMO energy, stronger ability to gain and lose electrons; (3) A-PpazoPorCo has superior bifunctional catalytic activity of oxygen reaction. The azo bonds in A-PpazoPorCo could further improve the adsorption capacity of catalytic ORR and OER intermediates, thus further improving the oxygen catalytic performance. A-PpazoPorCo have better catalytic oxygen reaction activity; (4) The unique D-π-A structure can further improve catalyst performance. The connection of D-π-A structure in A-PpazoPorCo can not only enhance molecular conjugation, but also further regulate the electron cloud density of A-PpazoPorCo, which improves the electron cloud density in the center of Co–N4, thus further improving the catalytic performance. A-PpazoPorCo with strong electron donor groups linked by azo bond has not been reported in the literature. This unique structure of the azo bond and −ph-NH2 design has unique advantages in achieving catalytic oxygen reactions. The COFs has large π bonds throughout the plane, an effect that makes it easy for the COFs to form a compact topology, resulting in low conductivity and catalytically active sites that cover each other. In order to solve this problem, electronic conductors with high specific surface area are used as carriers (carbon black [44], carbon nanotubes [1], graphene oxide [45], etc.) to reduce the stacked of COFs, so that they are evenly dispersed on the surface of the carbon material close to single layer, fully exposing the active site, and then improving the catalytic performance. Three-dimensional graphene (3D-G) has multiple pore channels, which has a large π bond and interact with FC-PorM-COFs to synergistically promote the oxygen-catalyzed reaction. 3D-G also has a high specific surface area, while its multistage pores can be enhanced mass transfer. After FC-PorM-COFs is supported on 3D-G, the π-π interaction between FC-PorM-COFs and 3D-G will increase the electron cloud density in the center of M−N4 in the COF, thus improving its catalytic activity. The π-π interaction between FC-PorM-COFs and 3D-G enhances the intermolecular force between the COF plane and 3D-G plane, resulting in improved catalytic durability. Herein, the COFs with –ph–NH2 edge poly(1,4-phenyldiazo porphyrin cobalt) (A-PpazoPorCo) was synthesized by adjusting the molar ratio of the reaction material. To make a better comparison, poly(1,4-phenyl-diazoporphyrin-cobalt) (PpazoPorCo) and –ph–NO2 edge poly(1,4-phenyl-diazoporphyrin-cobalt) (N-PpazoPorCo) with different donor/electron withdrawing groups were synthesized. The structure of A-PpazoPorCo was confirmed by ultraviolet visible spectroscopy (UV–Vis), infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR). The topological stacking structure of A-PpazoPorCo was simulated by XRD and material studios (MS). The morphology and microstructure were studied by TEM and HRTEM. The chemical composition and valence states of A-PpazoPorCo were characterized by XPS. TG was used to determine the thermal stability of A-PpazoPorCo. To further study the oxygen catalytic process of A-PpazoPorCo, the oxygen catalytic mechanism was studied by DFT calculation. The A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G catalyst was prepared by 3D-G, and the optimum synthesis conditions were studied. The composition, structure, morphology and valence state of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G were characterized, and its oxygen bifunctional catalytic performance was further evaluated. The preparation of A-PpazoPorCo and A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G are showed in Scheme 1 . 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials P-nitrobenzaldehyde, propionic acid, acetic acid, nitrobenzene, pyrrole, cobalt acetate, p-phenylenediamine were purchased from Sinopharm Reagent Co., LTD Reagent Co., Ltd. The coal bitumen was purchased from a local chemical company. Nanometer (20 nm) magnesium oxide and nanometer calcium carbonate were purchased from Taiji Ring Nano Co., Ltd. Nafion was acquired from DuPont. RuO2 and Pt/C (20.0%) were purchased from Suzhou Shengernuo Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals are AR grade and can be used without further purification. TNPorH2 was homemade (see supporting material S1.1 for synthesis method). 2.2 Synthesis of A-PpazoPorCo The 0.85 g TNPorCo (see supporting material S1.2 for synthesis method) and 0.32 g p-phenylenediamine were dissolved in 50 mL DMF, respectively. The two solutions were added to the same three-necked flask and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The 2.24 g (40 mmol) KOH was dispersed in 50 mL DMF and then poured into the three-necked flask and reacted at 150℃ in a N2 atmosphere for 24 h. The reaction mixture was filtered, washed and filtered with water and ethanol respectively, and then recrystallized with DMF for 3 times. The filtered residue was placed in a vacuum drying oven and dried at 60℃ for 24 h to obtain purple-black solid powder A-PpazoPorCo (0.85 g, yield ∼ 80.01%). The preparation methods of PpazoPorCo and N-PpazoPorCo were similar to A-PpazoPorCo (The structural formulas of PpazoPorCo and N-PpazoPorCo are shown in Figs. S5 and S6.). The dosage of other materials remained unchanged, and the p-phenylenediamine was adjusted to 0.21 g (2 mmol) and 0.11 g (1 mmol), respectively. Purple-black solid powder PpazoPorCo (0.81 g, yield ∼ 75.08%) and purple-black solid powder N-PpazoPorCo (0.42 g, yield ∼ 79.1%) were obtained, respectively. To further compare FC-PorM-COFs and monocyclic PorM, meso-5, 10, 15, 20-tetra (p-methyl-phenyl-azo) porphyrin Co (TmepazoPorCo) was synthesized (see supporting material S1.3 for synthesis method). In order to discuss the interaction between azo bond and Co–N4 site, previously reported PTPPCo was prepared for comparison [46], and its structural formula is shown in Fig. S7. 2.3 Preparation of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G The 0.10 g A-PpazoPorCo was completely dissolved in 50 mL DMF, while 0.10 g 3D-G was well dispersed in 50 mL DMF (For the preparation method of 3D-G, see supporting material S2). The above solution was mixed with reflux for 24 h, distilled to near-dry, dried in a drying oven at 70℃ for 12 h, and then heat treated at 400℃ in a N2 for 2 h to obtain a black solid powder A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G (0.19 g, yield ∼ 97.5%). PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, TmepazoPorCo/3D-G, TNPorCo/3D-G and PTPPCo/3D-G were prepared by the same method, with the only difference being the replacement of A-PpazoPorCo with PpazoPorCo, N-PpazoPorCo TmepazoPorCo, TNPorCo or PTPPCo, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization and performance tests of A-PpazoPorCo The UV–Vis spectra of TNPorCo and A-PpazoPorCo were examined. Both samples have two characteristic absorption peaks (Fig. 1 a). These two peaks belong to the Soret band (423 and 437 nm) of the porphyrin and the Q-band (535 and 554 nm) of the porphyrin characteristic peaks, respectively. Compared with TNPorCo, the Soret band and Q-band of A-PpazoPorCo are redshifted by 14 and 19 nm, respectively, which is mainly due to the increase of delocalization energy of the porphyrin plane caused by the conjugation effect of A-PpazoPorCo. The UV–Vis spectrum of TmepazoPorCo shows the Soret band and Q-band of porphyrin (Fig. S9). Compared with TNPorCo, the Soret band and Q-band of TmepazoPorCo are redshifted by 6 nm and 2 nm, respectively. This indicates the successful introduction of strong electron donor groups of TmepazoPorCo. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) further confirmed the synthesis process of A-PpazoPorCo (Fig. 1b). A-PpazoPorCo has three main peaks at 1620 cm−1 (–CN–), 3519 cm−1 (–NH2), and 1451 cm−1 (–NN–) [40,47]. TNPorCo has three main peaks located at 1601 cm−1 (–CN–), 1516 cm−1 (–NO2) and 1346 cm−1 (–NO2). Compared with TNPorCo, the vibrational strength of –NO2 in A-PpazoPorCo is weakened, and stronger –NN– appears, which proves that –NO2 reacts with –NH2 to produce –NN–. FT-IR spectra of TmepazoPorCo show two main peaks at 1451 cm−1 (–NN–) and 2980 cm−1 (–CH3) (Fig. S10). The disappearance of –NO2 can prove that the reaction between –NH2 and –NO2 generates –NN–. According to the solid-state 13C NMR spectrum of A-PpazoPorCo (Fig. 1c), peaks at 143.71, 134, 119.45 and 109.7 ppm are characteristic peaks of porphyrin rings. The peak value associated with the –C–NN–C– bond is about 151.2 ppm [40,48], further indicating the successful synthesis of A-PpazoPorCo. A-PpazoPorCo adopts an eclipsed stacking in a PM space group with refined cell parameters of a = 23 Å, b = 23 Å, and c = 3 Å. The experimental results are simulated results with R wp of 2.15% and R p of 1.16%, respectively [49,50]. Eclipsed (A-A) stacking structures were simulated for the A-PpazoPorCo, and the simulated PXRD patterns of the eclipsed structures have a much better agreement with the experimental results (Fig. 1d). Fig. S8a and b show the SEM of A-PpazoPorCo, which indicate that A-PpazoPorCo is stacked, and TEM further proved that A-PpazoPorCo is two-dimensional nanosheet morphology with lamellar deposits (Fig. 1e). In the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images of A-PpazoPorCo (Fig. 1f), the d-spacing is 0.215 nm and belongs to the (220) plane of A-PpazoPorCo. Selected electron diffraction can also show the diffraction pattern of the (220) plane, which is consistent with the results of Fig. 1d. The porous structure of A-PpazoPorCo was studied by BET. A-PpazoPorCo display similar IV-types (Fig. S11). A-PpazoPorCo has a surface area of 82 m2/g. The pore size distribution curves show A-PpazoPorCo has pore sizes of 2.1 nm, which corresponded to the A-A stacking style. As show in Fig. 1g, the mass loss of TNPorCo at 400℃ is 16.4%, indicating that TNPorCo has begun to decompose at 400℃, while the mass loss of A-PpazoPorCo at 400℃ is negligible, indicating that A-PpazoPorCo does not decompose at 400℃. The mass loss at 600℃ is only 4.8%, indicating that A-PpazoPorCo has better thermal stability than TNPorCo. Fig. S12 prove that TmepazoPorCo began to decompose at 281℃ and lost 15.4% weight at 400℃. The results show that the azo bond part of TmepazoPorCo is decomposed. The elemental composition and valence states of A-PpazoPorCo were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The total spectrum of A-PpazoPorCo prove that A-PpazoPorCo contains elements such as C, N, O and Co (Fig. S13a). The content of each element can be further seen from Table S1. As shown in Fig. S13b, C 1 s peaks are divided into 288.7, 284.8 and 286 eV peaks, corresponding to C–N, C–C and CN, respectively. The N 1 s spectrum of A-PpazoPorCo contains C–N, Co–N, NN, CN and N–H (Fig. 1h), corresponding to 400.7, 400.08, 401.8, 399.01 and 397.8 eV, respectively [51]. Where NN occurs because –NH2 and –NO2 are synthesized by reaction, and the absence of N–O or NO indicates that –NO2 in the compound is involved in the reaction. In the Co 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 1i), two sets of peaks appear at 780.6/795.8 eV representing Co3+ 2p 3/2 and Co3+ 2p 1/2 of A-PpazoPorCo, respectively. Two peaks representing Co2+ 2p 3/2 and Co2+ 2p 1/2 of A-PpazoPorCo appear at 782.3/798.1 eV [52]. 3.2 Characterization and performance of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G The catalyst was subjected to characterization using UV–Vis diffuse reflectance tests. These were conducted for both A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G and A-PpazoPorCo, as evidenced by the results presented in Fig. 2 a. Compared with A-PpazoPorCo, the Soret band and Q-band of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G are redshifted by 10 and 25 nm, respectively. The π-π interaction between A-PpazoPorCo and 3D-G is confirmed. Then Raman spectra of the A-PpazoPorCo and 3D-G were shown in Fig. 2b. There are two strong peaks and one weak peak in the two materials, which are related to the overtones of the D-band, G-band and 2D band of the carbon material, respectively. Compared with 3D-G, A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has a G-band redshift of 7 cm−1, indicating that the strong π-π interaction between A-PpazoPorCo and 3D-G is occurred [50]. The I D/I G = 0.987 of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is larger than 3D-G (I D/I G = 0.901). The results show that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has more abundant defect structure than 3D-G, which is more conducive easy to exposing the active site. 3D-G and A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G were detected by X-ray diffractometer (Fig. 2c). Both A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G and 3D-G have a wide peak at 2θ = 21.5° and no other diffraction peaks, indicating that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is an amorphous state as 3D-G [39]. The results show that A-PpazoPorCo distributed uniformly on the catalyst surface without stack, which can also prove that there is no decomposition into Co-N-C atomic clusters during the HT process. Fig. S8e, f show that the SEM of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is a carbon foam structure with multi-level pores, similar to that of 3D-G graphene (Fig. S8c, d). TEM images prove that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has a foamy porous structure (Fig. 2d). HR-TEM prove that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is a graphene-like structure (Fig. 2e). Compared with HR-TEM of A-PpazoPorCo (Fig. 1f), there are no visible spot streaks, indicating that A-PpazoPorCo does not accumulate on the surface of 3D-G, is evenly distributed, and is not decomposed during HT [53]. The SAED of A-PpaPorCo/3D-G demonstrated that it is an amorphous structure (Fig. 2f). Through elemental analysis of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G by HAADF-STEM (Fig. 2g), it can be seen that C, N and Co of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G are uniformly distributed on the 3D-G surface (Fig. 2h–j). BET specific surface area tests were carried out on 3D-G and A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2k. 3D-G has a large specific surface area (1597 m2/g), and BET specific surface area (485 m2/g) decreased significantly after A-PpazoPorCo is supported in 3D-G. This is due to the A-PpazoPorCo occupying part of the pore channel, resulting in a reduction in specific surface area. Fig. 2i shows the pore size distribution curves of 20 nm MgO and 30 nm CaCO3 obtained by template method in 3D-G. Among them, the 0.8 nm micropore is the pore generated by the decomposition of CO2 by CaCO3. When A-PpazoPorCo is loaded on 3D-G, the pores at 0.8, 20 and 30 nm are significantly reduced, further indicating that the A-PpazoPorCo is loaded on 3D-G. The surface chemical phase and composition of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G were detected by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and it is found that C, N and Co elements existed (Fig. 2m). As can be seen from Table S1, the composition and proportion of elements in A-PpazoPorCo and A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G are similar, while the change of element composition in A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is caused by the anchor of A-PpazoPorCo on 3D-G surface. The ratio of Co elements in A-PpazoPorCo and A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is close to 2:1, which is consistent with the ratio of A-PpazoPorCo to 3D-G. As shown in Fig. 2n, C 1 s peaks are divided into 288.7, 284.8 and 286 eV peaks, corresponding to C-N, C–C and CN, respectively. The N 1 s spectrum of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G contains C–N, Co–N, NN, CN and NH, corresponding to 400.7, 400.08, 401.8, 399.01 and 397.8 eV, respectively (Fig. 2o) [54]. It can be seen that the valence states of C and N in A-PpazoPorCo and A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G have not changed [55]. In the Co 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 2p), two sets of peaks appear at 780.6/795.8 eV representing Co3+ 2p 3/2 and Co3+ 2p 1/2 of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, respectively. Two peaks representing Co2+ 2p 3/2 and Co2+ 2p 1/2 of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G appear at 782.3/798.1 eV. It shows that cobalt in A-PpazoPorCo and A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is in the intermediate oxidation state of Co2+ and Co3+. Combined with the XPS spectra the TG curves, A-PpazoPorCo has not decomposed to produce remained intact throughout the HT. Therefore, the catalytic active center of the catalyst is Co–N4 in A-PpazoPorCo. 3.3 Electrochemical performance test To investigate the optimum process conditions for catalyst preparation, the electrocatalytic ORR performance of A-PpazoPorCo and 3D-G with different immobilization ratios (1:2, 2:1 and 1:1) and HT at different temperatures (300, 400 500, and 600 °C) is discussed, as shown in Fig. S14a, b. Fig. S14a shows the E 1/2 of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is the highest when the mass of A-PpazoPorCo and 3D-G is 1:1, and Fig. S14b shows the maximum E 1/2 is reached at HT 400℃. Therefore, the optimum preparation conditions of the catalyst are as follows: the mass ratio of A-PpazoPorCo and 3D-G is 1:1 and HT at 400℃. The CV curves of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, 20 wt% Pt/C and TNPorCo/3D-G are shown in Fig. S15, and there is an obvious oxygen reduction peak, indicating that the catalyst has oxygen reduction catalytic performance. Compared with PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, TNPorCo/3D-G and 20 wt% Pt/C, A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G shows obvious oxygen reduction performance, indicating that it has the best catalytic performance. Catalyst catalysis ORR LSV test at 0.1 M KOH was shown in Fig. 3 a. The E 1/2 of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, TmepazoPorCo/3D-G, TNPorCo/3D-G and 20 wt% Pt/C are 0.880, 0.874, 0.861, 0.824, 0.816 and 0.860 V vs. RHE, respectively. A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has the largest E 1/2, indicating that it has the best catalytic activity for oxygen reduction. The Tafel curves obtained by further fitting of LSV are shown in Fig. 3b. The Tafel slopes of ORR for A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, TmepazoPorCo/3D-G, TNPorCo/3D-G and 20 wt% Pt/C are 59.1, 65, 85, 75, 80 and 74 mV dec−1, respectively. A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has the best catalytic ORR reaction kinetics. The full-speed ORR test was conducted on the A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G and TNPorCo/3D-G, the K-L curve is fitted to determine the electron transfer number (Fig. S16a, b). The electron transfer numbers of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpaPorCo/3D-G, and TNPorCo/3D-G are 3.97, 3.94, 3.89, and 3.78, respectively (Fig. S16c). The results show that the catalytic process of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is close to that of 4e−. The exact electron transfer numbers of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, 20 wt% Pt/C and TNPorCo/3D-G calculated by rotating ring electrode (RRDE) are 3.92, 3.91 and 3.75, respectively (Fig. 3c). A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G also has a low H2O2 yield, indicating that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has excellent selectivity. A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, TNPorCo/3D-G and 20 wt% Pt/C were tested by chronoamperometry (i-t) (Fig. 3d). After 45000 s, the current density of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G only decreased by 4.5%, which is better than 20 wt% Pt/C (decreased 25.6%) and TNPorCo/3D-G (decreased 26.8%), indicating that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G had the best durability. Fig. S17 shows the accelerated durability test (ADT) where the E 1/2 value of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G decays by only 10 mV after 5000 cycles CV. However, E 1/2 of 20 wt% Pt/C has a negative displacement of 42 mV, indicating that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has better durability. When A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G catalyst is immersed in KSCN (Fig. 3e), [SCN−] preferentially binds to Co2+, thereby preventing Co2+ from binding to oxygen and reducing its ORR catalytic activity. Fig. 3e shows that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G E 1/2 drops from 0.880 to 0.865 V vs. RHE. After oxygen saturation activation, the E 1/2 of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G recover from 0.865 to 0.879 V vs. RHE, indicating that [SCN−] is replaced by sufficient oxygen and the catalytic activity of ORR basically returned to the original performance. This indicates that the catalytic active center of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is Co–N4 in A-PpazoPorCo. The catalytic oxygen reaction performance is A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G > PpazoPorCo/3D-G > N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G. It can be concluded that the electron-donor group improves the catalytic performance, and the stronger the electron-donor ability, the higher the catalytic activity, while the electron-withdrawing group weakens the catalytic performance. Compared with TNPorCo, the strong electron donor groups of TmepazoPorCo can improve the catalytic performance. A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has better catalytic performance than TmepazoPorCo/3D-G, indicating that the fully conjugated structure of A-PpazoPorCo plays an important role in its catalytic activity. The π-π interaction between A-PpazoPorCo and 3D-G can enhance oxygen catalytic activity and durability of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G. The catalytic OER performance of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, RuO2, TmepazoPorCo/3D-G and TNPorCo/3D-G was tested in 1 M KOH, as shown in Fig. 3f [56–58]. At current density of 10 mA cm−2, the potentials of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, TmepazoPorCo/3D-G, TNPorCo/3D-G and RuO2 are 1.466, 1.532, 1.614, 1.658, 1.699 and 1.440 V vs. RHE, respectively. The overpotentials of the samples are 236, 323, 384, 428, 469 and 210 mV, respectively. The Tafel slope of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, PpazoPorCo/3D-G, N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, TmepazoPorCo/3D-G, TNPorCo/3D-G and RuO2 are 88, 95, 160, 235, 180 and 63 mV dec−1, respectively. The Tafel slope of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is close to RuO2, indicating that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has superior catalytic reaction kinetics. The chronoamperometry curves of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G and RuO2 at 1.466 V vs. RHE (1600 r min−1) show that the current density only decreases by 15.6% after 40000 s (Fig. 3h), which is better than RuO2 (25.7%). It shows that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has good OER durability. CV tests were performed on the prepared material at different sweep speeds (Fig. S18a–d), and the ECSA active surface area are obtained through fitting, as shown in Fig. 3i. The slope of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is 14.8 mF cm−1, which is higher than that of PpazoPorCo/3D-G (11 mF cm−1), N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G (9.7 mF cm−1) and TNPorCo/3D-G (9.6 mF cm−1), indicating that it contains more active sites. The bifunctional catalytic performance is evaluated by fitting the overpotential (△E = Ej =10-E 1/2), as shown in Fig. 3j. A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has a smaller potential difference (△E = 0.617 V) than PpazoPorCo/3D-G (0.705 V), N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G (0.781 V), TmepazoPorCo/3D-G (0.861 V), TNPorCo/3D-G (0.902 V), RuO2 (0.815 V) and 20 wt% Pt/C (1.096 V). By comparing the performance of different catalysts, it is proved that the catalytic oxygen kinetics of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G are the fast, the E 1/2 is the highest, the overpotential is the lowest, and the bifunctional catalytic oxygen performance is the highest (Fig. 3k). The catalytic ORR and catalytic OER properties of PTPPCo/3D-G were tested at 0.1 M KOH and 1 M KOH, respectively (Fig. S19a and b). The catalytic ORR E 1/2 of PTPPCo/3D-G is 0.865 V vs. RHE, and the catalytic OER E j=10 is 1.565 V vs. RHE. Further fitted, the total overpotential of PTPPCo/3D-G at 0.1 M KOH is 0.738 V (Fig. S19c). By comparing of PpazoPorCo/3D-G E 1/2 = 0.874 V vs. RHE, E j=10 = 1.532 V vs. RHE and △E (0.705 V), it can be proved that PpazoPorCo/3D-G has better catalytic oxygen reaction performance. It is further proved that the presence of azo bond can improve the catalytic performance of FC-PorM-COFs Co–N4 center. Among a series of catalysts prepared [59,60], it has the best bifunctional performance, which indicates that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is a bifunctional oxygen catalyst, which can be applied to ZABs. A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G showed better performance compared to previous reports (Table S2). A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has the best ORR and OER catalytic performance mainly due to the following factors: (1) It is determined by the structural characteristics of A-PpazoporCo, A-PpazoporCo is metal porphyrin COF connected by azo bonds. The entire plane of A-PpazoPorCo is highly conjugated and has excellent stability. A-PpazoporCo exhibits a low HOMO-LUMO energy gaps, facilitating electron gain and loss, which in turn enhances its catalytic performance; (2) As a nitrogen-rich structure, azo bond can improve the adsorption capacity of ORR and OER reaction intermediates, thus improving the catalytic performance; (3) The edge of A-PpazoPorCo is the strong electron donor group –ph–NH2. –Ph–NH2 can be combined with electron-withdrawing groups (azo bond) to increase the electron cloud density of the Co–N4 center, thereby improving the catalytic performance of A-PpazoPorCo; (4) The introduction of 3D-G can enhance the electrical conductivity of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G, and further improve the catalytic activity and catalytic durability through the π-π interaction between 3D-G and A-PpazoPorCo. 3.4 Mechanism simulation To further compare the TNPorCo and PpazoPorCo theoretically, the HOMO-LUMO of TNPorCo and PpazoPorCo were simulated by MS 2019, DMOl 3 module respectively. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the energy gap between HOMO-LUMO of TNPorCo is 1.333 eV and the PpazoPorCo is 0.319 eV. It can be shown that PpazoPorCo has a smaller energy gap and a stronger ability to gain and lose electrons, to effectively catalyze ORR and OER. The 4e− ORR pathways are studied on TNPorCo and PpazoPorCo models (Fig. 4b). As shown in Fig. 4c, the change of Gibbs free energy at two different electrode potentials U = 1.23 V and U = 0 V is studied. Compared to TNPorCo, PpazoPorCo has a lower energy barrier, thus resulting in its higher activity. This indicates that the nitrogen-rich environment in PpazoPorCo can enhance the catalytic oxygen reaction process.The band structure and density of state (DOS) of PpazoPorCo were further calculated by CASTEP module of MS. Band structure of PpaPorCo is shown in Fig. 4d, which shows that the Fermi energy level crosses the energy band of PpaPorCo, indicating the absence of the forbidden band. The above results indicate that the PpaPorCo has the property of a conductor. Fig. 4e shows the DOS of TNPorCo and PpazoPorCo. Compared with TNPorCo, PpazoPorCo has a lower d-band center. According to the d-band center theory, the lower d-band center will lead to the weakening of the binding effect between the catalyst and the intermediate, which is conducive to the desorption process and accelerates the oxygen catalysis process. To facilitate the calculation, the influence of electron donating group (–NH2) and electron withdrawing group (–NO2) on the electron cloud density of Co–N4 center was compared. Differential charges were calculated for TNPorCo (Fig. 4f), meso-5, 10, 15, 20-tetra (4-aminophenyl) porphyrin (TAPorCo) and PpazoPorCo (Fig. 4g and h) by MS CASTEP modeling. Red represents high electron cloud density; blue represents low electron cloud density. Compared with TNPorCo, the Co–N4 central electron cloud density of PpazoPorCo increased from 0.004 eV to 0.015 eV. The electron cloud density at the porphyrin center Co–N4 of TAPorCo is 0.006 eV, indicating that –NH2 at the edge of TAPorCo as an electron donor can further enhance the electron cloud density at the center of Co–N4. This shows that –ph–NH2 and azo bond can form a D-π-A structure to enhance the electron cloud density of Co–N4. 3.5 The evaluation of ZABs performance ZABs are an effective bifunctional catalyst device for evaluating oxygen reactions. The cathode catalyst of liquid zinc air battery (LZABs) with the A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is shown in Fig. 5 a. The discharge polarization curves of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G and liquid zinc-air batteries of 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 were tested the power density curves were obtained (Fig. 5b). A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has open circuit voltage and peak power density up to 1.50 V and 409.6 mW cm−2, better than 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 (1.350 V, 240 mW cm−2). The battery capacity of the LZABs under the condition of 10 mA cm−2 is shown in Fig. 5c. A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has a battery specific capacity of 780 mAh g−1 Zn, larger than the battery specific capacity of 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 (591 mAh g−1 Zn). The charge and discharge polarization curves of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G and 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 are shown in Fig. 5d. The current at 50 mA cm−2, the charge and discharge gaps of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G and 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 are 0.81 V and 1.34 V, respectively. The results show that the activity of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is higher than that of 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2. The electrode process of LZAB was analyzed by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) (Fig. 5e). The internal resistance (R Ω) and interfacial transfer resistance (R ct) of the LZABs with A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G as the cathode catalyst is 5 Ω and 11 Ω, respectively. It is smaller than that of with 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 as cathode catalyst (R o = 7 Ω, R ct = 20 Ω). The Nyquist diagram at A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G shows the closest diffusion to 45°, indicating that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has the fastest charge and mass transfer processes. The durability test of LZABs with A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G and 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 (Fig. 5f), the charging and discharging platform of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G ZAB shows no significant change after 2970 cycles (495 h), while the charging voltage increases while the discharge voltage decreases after only 660 cycles (110 h) of 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2. The LZABs assembled at A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G have excellent durability. The assembly of ZABs by A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G demonstrated favourable battery performance compared to previously reported catalysts (Table S3). The above tests also show that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is a superior bifunctional oxygen catalyst. The application of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G in flexible zinc-air batteries (FZABs) also has good performance. FZABs were assembled by A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G and 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 (Fig. 5g). As shown in Fig. 5h, A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G FZABs exhibits superior peak power density (66 mW cm−2), which is better than 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 (49 mW cm−2), indicating that FZAB of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has superior battery performance. FZABs containing A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has a long constant current discharge of 13.6 h (Fig. 5i), which is better than FZAB containing 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2 (10 h). The charge–discharge durability test shows that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G-FZAB has excellent durability (Fig. 5j). Fig. 5k shows that the FZABs with A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G can still work properly when bent by external forces. The above experiments also show that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G is an excellent bifunctional oxygen catalyst. 4 Conclusions In this study, the COFs with –ph–NH2 edge poly(1,4-phenyldiazo porphyrin cobalt) (A-PpazoPorCo) was synthesized by adjusting the molar ratio of the reaction material. Since A-PpazoPorCo has higher delocalization energy, it has better thermal stability and TG confirms that it remains undecomposed at 400℃. The π-π interaction between PpazoPorCo and 3D-G can enhance the catalytic activity and durability of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G. The catalytic activity of oxygen reaction was in the order of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G > PpazoPorCo/3D-G > N-PpazoPorCo/3D-G. This indicates that the presence of –ph–NH2 can improve the catalytic activity of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G. By comparing the catalytic oxygen reaction performance of PpazoPorCo and PTPPCo/3D-G, it is proved that the presence of azo bond can further enhance the catalytic performance of Co–N4 in FC-PorM-COFs. The calculated results of DFT are consistent with the experimental results, which proves that the electron cloud density transformation of Co–N4 site in PpazoPorCo is connected by azo bond. –Ph–NH2 combines with the azo bonds to form the D-π-A structure, which further increases the electron cloud density of Co–N4 in A-PpazoPorCo. The electron cloud density of M−N4 in FC-PorM-COFs is regulated by both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups. This binding method effectively solves the problem of difficult regulation of the active site. A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has demonstrated superior battery performance in both LZABs and FZABs. This is a strategy to construct efficient oxygen reaction bifunctional catalyst, and its good bifunctional performance will provide a valuable reference for the realization of fuel cells and water splitting technology. coredata.dc:description: Fully conjugated covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are widely used in electrocatalysis. The COF with –ph–NH2 edge poly(1,4-phenyldiazo porphyrin cobalt) (A-PpazoPorCo) is synthesized by adjusting the molar ratio of the reaction material, and exhibits high delocalization energy to significantly enhance thermal stability. The nitrogen in the azo bond improves the adsorption capacity for ORR and OER catalytic intermediates, while the –ph–NH2 group further increases the electron cloud density at the Co–N4 center in A-PpazoPorCo. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the strong electron-donating –ph–NH2 groups and the electron-donating azo bonds form an electron donor-π-electron acceptor (D-π-A) structure, which further enhances the electron cloud density. The strong π-π interaction between A-PpazoPorCo and three-dimensional graphene (3D-G) significantly boosts the oxygen catalytic performance of the A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G. The catalytic ORR half-wave potential (E 1/2) of A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G can reach 0.880 V vs. RHE. The total overpotential (△E = E j=10-E 1/2) is 0.617 V, demonstrating excellent bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance. The efficient oxygen catalytic performance indicates that A-PpazoPorCo/3D-G has the potential for application in fuel cells cathodes and overall water splitting anodes.
